attributes.alt: Book cover for The Things That I LOVE about TREES by Chris Butterworth and illustrated by Charlotte Voake. The cover art shows a huge tree with a little girl standing under it.

elements.text: The Things That I LOVE About TREES
Use Circle Time to build background, engage children with a song, and introduce vocabulary
Begin Story Time by introducing the book and asking,
What is one change that happens in a season?
Read interactively, using ordinal numbers to discuss the seasons.
Correctly use ordinal terms, including first through fifth, next, and last.
Use imagination to think about or picture something.
Identify that there is meaning in text.
Arrange Pattern Blocks representing fall leaves behind a “curtain.”
Challenge children to recreate the order of the leaves based on ordinal number descriptions.
What do we do during different seasons?
What book did you choose? Can you tell what season it is in the story?
Pretend to do an activity you like to do in the spring.
How can you make a flower out of Pattern Blocks? What will you do first?
Write about something that happens in the fall.
Draw something that you like to do in the fall.
Can you make any words with these letters?
What are you building? What did you do first?

attributes.alt: Book cover for The Things That I LOVE about TREES by Chris Butterworth and illustrated by Charlotte Voake. The cover art shows a huge tree with a little girl standing under it.

elements.text: The Things That I LOVE About TREES
Use Circle Time to share the Mind Builder
Begin Story Time by connecting the Mind Builder to
The Things That I LOVE About TREES.
Read closely to use imagination and review ordinal numbers.
Correctly use ordinal terms, including first through fifth, next, and last.
Use imagination to think about or picture something.
Identify that there is meaning in text.
Ask children to imagine four different trees they’ll arrange. Use Connecting Cubes to represent the trees.
Direct children to arrange the trees and use ordinal numbers to describe them.
What do we do during different seasons?
Why did you choose this book?
Imagine you are outside. What season is it? How do you feel?
Arrange Connecting Cubes in an order. What order are they in?
Imagine a spring day. Write about what you would do.
Draw a real or imaginary tree.
Can you find something in the room that starts with the sound /s/ like at the beginning of

attributes.alt: Book cover for The Things That I LOVE about TREES by Chris Butterworth and illustrated by Charlotte Voake. The cover art shows a huge tree with a little girl standing under it.

elements.text: The Things That I LOVE About TREES
Use Circle Time to practice using location words, and introduce vocabulary
The Things That I LOVE About TREES
What is one way that leaves change in a season?
Read interactively for deeper comprehension and to review location words.
Use position words such as “over,” “under,” “above,” “on,” “beside,” “next to,” “between,” “in front of,” “near,” and “far,” “top,” “bottom,” “up,” “down,” and “behind.
Use imagination to think about or picture something.
Identify that there is meaning in text.
Contribute ideas and participate in group writing.
Arrange Connecting Cubes behind a curtain and describe the arrangement with location terms.
Challenge children to recreate the arrangement based on description.
What do we do during different seasons?
What season is it in that book?
Can you pretend to be a tree during the fall?
Where is the top of this object? Where is the bottom?
Can you write about what happens to trees in the summer?
Can you draw your two favorite things in the classroom next to each other?
What is something you can do that starts with the /s/ sound?
Build a tall tower. What is the top like? What is the bottom like?

attributes.alt: Big Chart of Big Ideas for The Changing Seasons. The chart shows the four seasons and says, Winter: We skate and sled; Spring: We plant a garden; Summer: We picnic to the buzz of bees: Fall: We watch leaves turn.

elements.text: Big Chart of Big Ideas: The Changing Seasons

attributes.alt: Book cover for The Things That I LOVE about TREES by Chris Butterworth and illustrated by Charlotte Voake. The cover art shows a huge tree with a little girl standing under it.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to discuss the changing seasons and introduce vocabulary
Begin Story Time by connecting the texts
The Things That I LOVE About TREES
Read interactively and connect to counting.
Correctly use ordinal terms, including first through fifth, next, and last.
Use position words such as “over,” “under,” “above,” “on,” “beside,” “next to,” “between,” “in front of,” “near,” and “far,” “top,” “bottom,” “up,” “down,” and “behind.
Use imagination to think about or picture something.
Contribute ideas and participate in group writing.
Use Pattern Blocks to represent vegetables.
Have children use location terms to position the “plants.”
Challenge children to spot mistakes you make while “planting.”
What do we do during different seasons?
What did you like most about that book?
Pretend to plant in the spring. What do you need to do to plant?
Put these in order. Which is third? Which is fourth?
What will you write about first?
Draw a picture of a tree. Which season is it?
Can you draw the letters of your name in the sand? Which will you draw first?
Which two blocks are near each other? Could you build something in front of them?

attributes.alt: Book cover for The Things That I LOVE about TREES by Chris Butterworth and illustrated by Charlotte Voake. The cover art shows a huge tree with a little girl standing under it.

elements.text: The Things That I Love About Trees
Use Circle Time to connect the book to science and to have children act out activities that can be done in each season.
Start Story Time by revisiting the book and asking,
What happens during your favorite season?
Read and retell the story interactively for physical engagement and a focus on location.
Use position words such as “over,” “under,” “above,” “on,” “beside,” “next to,” “between,” “in front of,” “near,” and “far,” “top,” “bottom,” “up,” “down,” and “behind.
Use imagination to think about or picture something.
Identify that there is meaning in text.
Contribute ideas and participate in group writing.
Support children as they independently respond to this week’s prompt:
Which season do you like best? What happens first in that season?
Save children’s writing for display next week.
What do we do during different seasons?
Does anyone in the story do something special that they can only do during a specific season?
Pretend you are going outside during the winter. Show what you have to do before you go outside. What do you need to wear?
Who is next to you? Who is in front of you? Who is behind you?
Imagine two trees standing next to each other during your favorite season. Write about them.
Can you draw a picture of a tree in the winter?
What sounds do you hear in the word
What are you building? Tell me the steps you took to build this.
